info.author: Loïc Peron
info.description:
simpy_events
=======================

|license| |build-status| |docs|

.. |license| image:: https://img.shields.io/github/license/loicpw/simpy_events.svg
.. |build-status| image:: https://travis-ci.org/loicpw/simpy_events.svg?branch=master
    :target: https://travis-ci.org/loicpw/simpy_events
.. |docs| image:: https://readthedocs.org/projects/simpy-events/badge/?version=latest
    :target: http://simpy-events.readthedocs.io/en/latest/?badge=latest
    :alt: Documentation Status

This project was created in order to ease code reusing when creating 
simulations with `simpy`_

It provides an event framework the way python `logging`_ module works:




- module.py:

.. code-block:: python

    from simpy_events import Event
    ev = Event('foo.bar')

    def process(env):
        value = yield ev(env.timeout(1, value='a')))

- other_module.py: 

.. code-block:: python

    from simpy_events import Event
    top_event = Event('foo')

    @top_event.callbacks
    def when_processing_event(origin, event, *args, **kw):
        print('processing the event, origin is "{origin}"'
              ', event value is "{value}".format(origin=origin,
                                                 value=event.value))

- main.py:

.. code-block:: python

    import simpy
    import module 
    import other_module
    env = simpy.Environment()
    env.process(module.process(env))
    env.run()

.. code-block:: bash

    $ python main.py
    processing the event, origin is "Event(foo.bar)", event value is "a"

The event core system is the same as python `logging`_ module, but it
doesn't use it. The code has been duplicated and modified so it works
whatever the runtime logging setup is.

.. warning:: works only in python 3

install and test
=======================

production install
********************

using pip:

.. code-block:: bash

    $ pip install -r requirements.txt
    $ pip install .

There is also a makefile in the project root directory, which does the
same:

.. code-block:: bash

    $ make install

run the tests
******************

Use the makefile in the project root directory:

.. code-block:: bash

    $ make test

This runs the tests generating a coverage html report

dev install
****************

There is a makefile in the project root directory:

.. code-block:: bash

    $ make dev

Using pip, the above is equivalent to:

.. code-block:: bash

    $ pip install -r requirements-dev.txt                                             
    $ pip install -e .


.. note:: in order to keep requirements file alphabetically sorted and
          keep comments, use the makefile to **pip freeze** which will
          generate a **.pipfreeze.txt** file containing sorted result,
          and then edit the actual files manually:

          .. code-block:: bash

            $ make freeze

build the doc
******************

The documentation is made with sphinx, you can use the makefile in the
project root directory to build html doc:

.. code-block:: bash

    $ make doc

Documentation
=======================

Documentation on `Read The Docs`_.
